title: Surfing and Travel
text: I am so grateful to have had the opportunity to travel around the world and to surf in so many amazing places! As a surfer, the ocean is a second home to me, and this is one of the reasons I am so motivated to be an advocate for the ocean. Traveling and witnessing so much beautiful nature has left me even more empowered to protect it.

title: Surfing and Travel
text:
Interactive Surf Map

library(leaflet)
library(leaflet.extras)
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.4     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

# Load your surf data (make sure the CSV is in the "data/" folder)
surf_data <- read_csv("surfandtravel/surf_spots.csv") %>%
  rename_with(tolower) %>%  # makes column names lowercase
  rename(
    site = site,
    city = city,
    lat = lat,
    lon = lon,
    country = country,
    wave_type = `wave type`,
    notes = notes
  ) %>%
  filter(site != "Cardiff Reef")  # hides Cardiff Reef

Rows: 35 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (5): Site, City, Country, Wave Type, Notes
dbl (2): Lat, Lon

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

# Build the map
surf_map <- leaflet(data = surf_data, options = leafletOptions(worldCopyJump = TRUE)) %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$Esri.WorldImagery, group = "Satellite View") %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$OpenStreetMap, group = "Street Map") %>%

  addMiniMap(toggleDisplay = TRUE, minimized = TRUE) %>%

  # Start with a global view
  setView(lng = 0, lat = 0, zoom = 2) %>%

  addMarkers(
    lng = ~lon,
    lat = ~lat,
    popup = ~paste0(
      "<b>", site, "</b><br>",
      city, ", ", country, "<br>",
      "Wave type: ", wave_type, "<br>",
      "<i>", notes, "</i>"
    ),
    group = "Surf Spots"
  ) %>%

  addLayersControl(
    baseGroups = c("Satellite View", "Street Map"),
    overlayGroups = c("Surf Spots")
  ) %>%

  addResetMapButton()

# Display the map
surf_map





```

Photos from my Surf Travels



Logging in Noosa, on the sunshine coast of Australia





Cylinder Beach, North Stradbroke Island - Queensland, Australia





Pipes in Encinitas, California - my home break!





Crescent Head, Australia!





Manu Bay, Raglan, New Zealand




Next On My Surf Bucket List
I feel so grateful to have had the chance to surf all over my home state of California, as well as extensively in Australia, New Zealand, and Mexico! My dream is to travel the world one surf town at a time. Below is my bucket list of places I would love to surf:

Bali, Indonesia
Tahiti
Kamakura, Japan
North Shore, Oahu, Hawaii
Portugal
Nicaragua
The Oregon Coast
Hossegor, France
San Sebastian, Spain
Tofino, Canada

title: Mary Holtam
text:
Welcome! Thank you for visiting my site.
I am a 3rd-year student at the University of California, Santa Barbara, pursuing a Bachelor’s of Science in Environmental Studies to drive change through science and policy. I am the president of the Isla Vista Surfrider Foundation and am passionate about the intersection between ocean accessibility, conservation, and the surf industry.
On this site, you’ll find more about my work, passions, and projects. Feel free to explore - and reach out if you’d like to collaborate or connect!

title: How I Made This Website
text:
Thank you so much for visiting my website!!
I coded this website myself using Quarto and R-Studio. I learned these skills in my Statistics for Environmental Science class at UC Santa Barbara, ENVS193DS. I believe having these coding skills will be very helpful when working in environmental jobs in the future. Thank you to An Bui and Thuy-Tien Bui for their mentorship and support in building this website!
Here is an example of some code and its output from another assignment in this course:

<p><a href="codephotos.pdf">Download PDF</a>.</p>

This code shows how I created a box plot in R for a homework assignment earlier in the course. In this box plot, I am comparing my daily step count to the day of the week. I began this research project the first week of spring quarter, recording how many steps I took each day. I kept track of the day of the week, along with other factors such as the weather, whether or not I had work that day or had completed another workout, and how many hours I had class that day. However, in this box plot, I just compared my step count with the day of the week. I was interested in discovering how much my step count varies from day to day depending on which weekday it is. The information gathered from this box plot was quite interesting, as I had the greatest amount of steps on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday. I do not have class on these days, so I would have expected to have a higher number of steps on days that I do have class as I am walking to and from campus a lot. However, it makes sense that on my days off I would have more time to go on long walks and would not be sitting down for prolonged periods of time. The reason I decided to look into this is because remaining active is very important to me and I wanted to be aware of what days of the week I need to be more intentional about getting more steps in. It was a very fun project!

title: North Stradbroke Research Project
text:
While studying abroad at the University of Queensland, I had the opportunity to complete a research project while staying at the Moreton Bay Research Station on Minjerribah, North Stradbroke Island, Queensland.
The project studied the concentration of microplastics in sediment cores to determine whether the deposition in sediment has increased over time.
Please read the paper below to find out more.

<p><a href="research_essay.pdf">Download PDF</a>.</p>

title: Education
text:
Concentration in Marine Biology September 2022 - June 2026 University of California, Santa Barbara

Honors college
Environmental studies program scholarship recepient




August - November 2024 The University of Queensland, Australia During this three month program, I gained valuable research and field study experience. I completed two research projects- one focused on fish-feeding patterns and the other on microplastic deposition in sediment. You can find more details about these studies in the projects tab. I also conducted field work in Lamington National Park and Carnarvon Gorge, where I developed practical skills such as species identification, quadrat sampling, and transect surveys.



Physics, chemistry, biology, oceanography, statistics and data science, calculus, agroecology

title: My Work With the Surfrider Foundation
text:
The Surfrider Foundation is a nonprofit organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of the world’s oceans, waves, and beaches for all people, supported by a powerful activist network. I have been involved with the organization for the past seven years and remain deeply aligned with its goals- from reducing plastic pollution and promoting beach access to protecting clean water. Please continue reading to learn more about my work with the foundation.







2025 - present
The Surfrider Foundation Isla Vista club is one of the most active Surfrider student clubs in the world, and among the largest environmental organizations at UCSB. Our club is made up of 125 members and 9 committees. I served as vice president for a year before being elected co-president. My duties and accomplishments in this role include:

Increasing club membership by 20% during my vice presidency
Collaborating with local brand Island View Outfitters to create a Surfrider-themed collection to raise awareness and funds for our cause
Helping to collect over 1,000 dollars worth of prizes for our annual Concert for the Coast fundraiser
Planning speaker events with famous world champion surfers, local business owners, and artists
Handling club communications, outreach to local businesses and national partners, and recruitment in the fall




2025 - present
Selected into a group of 14 Surfrider club leaders from across the country.

Monthly meetings and trainings to develop advocacy and leadership skills
Presented to legislators at Hill Day in Washington DC and California Oceans Day in Sacramento to advocate for bills that reduce plastic, restrict offshore drilling, and protect clean water.




2022 - 2024
Was admitted onto this committee during my freshman year at UCSB and served for a year before being elected vice-president.

Canvassed door-to-door to homes in Isla Vista to provide educational materials on recycling
Organized petition in support of reduced plastic usage at UCSB dining halls
Created weekly “Trash Talk Tuesday” posts to educate Instagram users about plastic and waste reduction
Designed sign to post at local beaches that displays the current water quality




2021 - 2022

Arranged beach cleanups, fundraising campaigns, and biweekly meetings with members



Contacted over fifty San Diego County restaurants to inform them about the Ocean Friendly Restaurants program. Successfully helped to implement this program in multiple restaurants to prioritize plastic reduction, proper recycling, and sustainable food practices.




2023 - present

Visits and contacts restaurants in San Diego County to inform them about the Ocean Friendly Restaurants program which helps transition eateries to more sustainable practices
Tables at events such as beach cleanups to bring awareness to this committee
Acted in a training video that is shown to future volunteers




2019

Corresponded with Skip the Plastic Norwalk
Represented the youth voice by petitioning, presenting, and speaking at city council meetings to successfully campaign for a plastic bag ban in New Canaan and Norwalk, CT

title: Resume
text:
March 2025- Present
Co-president of one of the largest environmental organizations at UC Santa Barbara containing 9 committees and 120 members. Manages secretarial tasks such as club communications and meeting planning. Plans community events and outreach to local businesses and national partners. Works with the larger Surfrider Foundation to incorporate its goals of protecting the world’s oceans, waves, and beaches for all people into the Isla Vista community.



Jan 2025- Present
Selected into group of 14 Surfrider club leaders from across the country. Monthly meetings and trainings to develop advocacy and leadership skills and share ideas to improve our Surfrider clubs. Presented to legislators at Hill Day in Washington DC and California Oceans Day in Sacramento to advocate for bills that reduce plastic, restrict offshore drilling, and protect clean water.



Mar 2024- Mar 2025



Sep 2022- Mar 2024
Helps to reduce the plastic pollution of the UC Santa Barbara and Isla Vista community through beach cleanups, advocacy, and community events. Organized a petition in support of reduced plastic usage at the UCSB dining halls. Weekly meetings to work to accomplish these goals.



June 2023 - present
Visits and contacts restaurants in San Diego County to inform them about the Ocean Friendly Restaurants program which helps transition eateries to more sustainable practices. Tables at events such as beach cleanups to bring awareness to this committee. Acted in a training video that is shown to future volunteers.






Jun 2024 - Present
Sets up booth and assists volunteers at beach cleanups and community events. Assists with online administrative duties including social media management. Shares information about the foundation’s programs and projects to promote environmental stewardship among future generations.



Apr 2021 - Jun 2024
One of 8 students admitted. Advocates against the plastic pollution emergency through beach cleanups and recycling campaigns. Operates the foundation’s TikTok account to spread environmental education through video creation. Monthly meetings with foundation board members to evaluate progress & identify goals.






Jun 2024 - Present
Ensures that surf team events are following sustainable practices. Hosts community service events.




Feb 2024 - Present
Coaches children aged 6-13 in a variety of ocean-related activities including surfing, paddleboarding, tidepooling, and environmental education. Seeks to create an equitable space by removing barriers to ocean accessibility. Inspires young people to care for the ocean.





Oct 2023 - Jun 2024
Supports water conservation efforts of the Greek chapters of UC Santa Barbara and the greater Isla Vista community through Meatless Monday campaigns and water-saving challenges.






Jun 2022 - Present
Works with 40 six and seven-year-olds each morning in the summer. Teaches ocean safety skills, marine life awareness, and beach games while fostering a love and appreciation for the ocean.

title: About Me
text:
I am a third year environmental science student at UC Santa Barbara. I am a passionate environmental advocate, ocean lover, and surfer. I hope to pursue a career in environmental policy and science, pushing for accessible oceans for all people. Click on any of the links below to learn about my education, experience with The Surfrider Foundation, professional experience, or skills and certifications!
